ai-ud5.5:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the Eastern Monastery, the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother.
ai-ud5.5:1.3_0: On one occasion on the observance day, he was seated surrounded by the Sangha of monks.
ai-ud5.5:2.1_0: Then, when the night was well advanced and the first part of the night was over, Venerable Ānanda got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha and said,
ai-ud5.5:2.2_0: “Sir, the night is getting late. It is the first watch of the night, and the visiting mendicants have been sitting long.
ai-ud5.5:2.3_0: if he leaves out the first watch,
ai-ud5.5:2.4_0: for a long time the Community of monks has been sitting,
ai-ud5.5:2.5_0: may the Fortunate One, venerable Sir, recite the Pātimokkha for the monks.”
ai-ud5.5:2.6_0: When this was said, the Fortunate One remained silent.
ai-ud5.5:3.1_0: For a second time, as the night was getting late, in the middle watch of the night, Ānanda got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha and said,
ai-ud5.5:3.2_0: “Sir, the night is getting late. It is the first watch of the night, and the visiting mendicants have been sitting long.
ai-ud5.5:3.3_0: the middle watch of the night has gone out.
ai-ud5.5:3.4_0: for a long time the Community of monks has been sitting,
ai-ud5.5:3.5_0: may the Fortunate One, venerable Sir, recite the Pātimokkha for the monks.”
ai-ud5.5:3.6_0: But for a second time the Buddha kept silent.
ai-ud5.5:4.1_0: For a third time, as the night was getting late, in the last watch of the night, Ānanda got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha and said,
ai-ud5.5:4.2_0: “Sir, the night is getting late. It is the first watch of the night, and the visiting mendicants have been sitting long.
ai-ud5.5:4.3_0: Since he came out, the last watch of the night has gone out,
ai-ud5.5:4.6_0: for a long time the Community of monks has been sitting,
ai-ud5.5:4.7_0: may the Fortunate One, venerable Sir, recite the Pātimokkha for the monks.”
ai-ud5.5:4.8_0: And the Buddha replied, “Ānanda, the gathering is impure.”
ai-ud5.5:5.2_0: “With regard to which person did the Fortunate One say this:
ai-ud5.5:5.4_0: Then he focused on comprehending the minds of everyone in the Saṅgha.
ai-ud5.5:5.5_0: And he saw that person—immoral, with bad qualities, impure and dubious in conduct, hiding his actions, not an ascetic while claiming to be one, not abstaining from sexuality while claiming to do so, rotten inside, lustful, defiled—seated in the midst of the Sangha of monks.
ai-ud5.5:5.6_0: He went up to him and said,
ai-ud5.5:5.7_0: he asked that monk to leave.
ai-ud5.5:5.8_0: You can’t live in communion with the mendicants.”
ai-ud5.5:6.1_0: For a second time and a third time,
ai-ud5.5:6.2_0: he asked that monk to leave.
ai-ud5.5:6.3_0: You can’t live in communion with the mendicants.”
ai-ud5.5:6.5_0: For a third time that person was silent.
ai-ud5.5:7.1_0: Then Venerable Mahāmoggallāna took that person by the arm, ejected him out the gate, and bolted the door. Then he went up to the Buddha, and asked him,
ai-ud5.5:7.1_1: and after going, he said this to the Fortunate One:
ai-ud5.5:7.4_0: may the Fortunate One, venerable Sir, recite the Pātimokkha for the monks.”
ai-ud5.5:7.5_0: “It is wonderful, Moggallāna, it is marvellous, Moggallāna,
ai-ud5.5:7.6_0: how that silly man waited to be taken by the arm!”
ai-ud5.5:8.1_0: Then the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
ai-ud5.5:8.2_0: “From now on I won’t do the observance-day procedure or recite the Monastic Code.
ai-ud5.5:8.3_0: You will be doing it instead.
ai-ud5.5:8.4_0: It’s impossible, mendicants, it can’t happen that a Realized One could recite the monastic code in an impure assembly.
ai-ud5.5:9.1_0: Seeing these eight incredible and amazing things the demons love the ocean.
ai-ud5.5:9.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by eight?
ai-ud5.5:10.1_0: The ocean slopes and inclines gradually. It does not drop off all at once.
ai-ud5.5:10.2_0: The ocean gradually slants, slopes, and inclines, with no abrupt precipice.
ai-ud5.5:10.3_0: This is the first thing the demons love about the ocean.
ai-ud5.5:11.1_0: The ocean is steady. It does not go beyond the shoreline.
ai-ud5.5:11.2_0: The ocean is consistent and doesn’t overflow its boundaries.
ai-ud5.5:11.3_0: This is the second thing the demons love about the ocean.
ai-ud5.5:12.1_0: Furthermore, the ocean does not endure a dead corpse,
ai-ud5.5:12.1_1: but quickly carries it to the shore and strands it on the beach.
ai-ud5.5:12.2_0: But when the ocean is dead, it quickly typically sinks by a dead corpse, a pit of clay.
ai-ud5.5:12.3_0: This is the third thing the demons love about the ocean.
ai-ud5.5:13.1_0: Furthermore, when they reach the ocean, all the great rivers—that is, the Ganges, Yamunā, Aciravatī, Sarabhū, and Mahī—reach the ocean, they lose their former names and become known simply as the ocean.
ai-ud5.5:13.1_1: ‘the ocean’ is reckoned as a great man.
ai-ud5.5:13.2_0: When they reach the ocean, all the great rivers—that is, the Ganges, Yamunā, Aciravatī, Sarabhū, and Mahī—lose their names and clans and are simply considered ‘the ocean’.
ai-ud5.5:13.3_0: This is the fourth thing the demons love about the ocean.
ai-ud5.5:14.1_0: Whatever rivers in the world flow into the ocean and whatever rain falls into it, the ocean is not diminished or filled up because of that.
ai-ud5.5:14.2_0: For all the world’s streams that reach it, and the rain that falls from the sky, the ocean never empties or fills up.
ai-ud5.5:14.3_0: This is the fifth thing the demons love about the ocean.
ai-ud5.5:15.1_0: Furthermore, monks, the great ocean has one taste, the taste of salt.
ai-ud5.5:15.2_0: The ocean has just one taste, the taste of salt.
ai-ud5.5:15.3_0: This is the sixth thing the demons love about the ocean.
ai-ud5.5:16.1_0: Furthermore, monks, the great ocean has many precious things,
ai-ud5.5:16.1_1: Here are these treasures: beryl, mother-of-pearl, quartz, coral, silver, gold, rubies, and cat’s eyes.
ai-ud5.5:16.2_0: The ocean is full of many kinds of treasures, such as pearls, gems, beryl, conch, quartz, coral, silver, gold, rubies, and emeralds.
ai-ud5.5:16.3_0: This is the seventh thing the demons love about the ocean.
ai-ud5.5:17.1_0: Furthermore, many great beings live in the ocean, such as leviathans, leviathan-gulpers, leviathan-gulper-gulpers, demons, dragons, and fairies.
ai-ud5.5:17.1_1: This is the name of the Gandhabbas, there are three kinds of scents, namely, the dragons, and fairies.
ai-ud5.5:17.1_2: individuals of three hundred leagues, or even two hundred, three hundred, four hundred, or five hundred leagues.
ai-ud5.5:17.2_0: There are great beings in the ocean—sea-monsters, antigods, dragons, and divinities; creatures with bodies one thousand kilometers long, two thousand, three thousand, four thousand, and five thousand kilometers long.”
ai-ud5.5:17.2_1: and individuals of five hundred leagues.
ai-ud5.5:17.3_0: This is the eighth thing the demons love about the ocean.
ai-ud5.5:17.4_0: Seeing these eight incredible and amazing things the demons love the ocean.
ai-ud5.5:18.1_0: In the same way, seeing eight incredible and amazing things, mendicants, the mendicants love this teaching and training.
ai-ud5.5:18.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by eight?
ai-ud5.5:19.1_0: Just as the ocean slopes and inclines gradually, and does not drop off all at once,
ai-ud5.5:19.2_0: In the same way in this teaching and training the penetration to enlightenment comes from gradual training, progress, and practice, not abruptly.
ai-ud5.5:19.3_0: In this teaching and training the penetration to enlightenment comes from gradual training, progress, and practice, not abruptly.
ai-ud5.5:19.4_0: This is the first thing the mendicants love about this teaching and training.
ai-ud5.5:20.1_0: Just as the ocean is steady and does not go beyond the shoreline,
ai-ud5.5:20.2_0: In the same way, when a training rule is laid down for my disciples they wouldn’t break it even for the sake of their own life.
ai-ud5.5:20.3_0: Since I laid down this training rule for my disciples they wouldn’t break it even for the sake of their own life.
ai-ud5.5:20.4_0: This is the second thing the mendicants love about this teaching and training.
ai-ud5.5:21.1_0: Just as the ocean does not endure a dead corpse,
ai-ud5.5:21.1_1: but quickly carries it to the shore and strands it on the beach.
ai-ud5.5:21.2_0: In the same way, the Saṅgha doesn’t accommodate a person who is unethical, of bad qualities, filthy, with suspicious behavior, underhand, no true ascetic or spiritual practitioner—though claiming to be one—rotten inside, corrupt, and depraved.
ai-ud5.5:21.2_1: but quickly having assembled together, suspend him,
ai-ud5.5:21.2_2: But they quickly gather and expel them. Even if such a person is sitting in the middle of the Saṅgha, they’re far from the Saṅgha, and the Saṅgha is far from them.
ai-ud5.5:21.3_0: But the Saṅgha doesn’t accommodate a person who is unethical, of bad qualities, filthy, with suspicious behavior, underhand, no true ascetic or spiritual practitioner—though claiming to be one—rotten inside, corrupt, and depraved.
ai-ud5.5:21.3_2: But they quickly gather and expel them. Even if such a person is sitting in the middle of the Saṅgha, they’re far from the Saṅgha, and the Saṅgha is far from them.
ai-ud5.5:21.4_0: This is the third thing the mendicants love about this teaching and training.
ai-ud5.5:22.1_0: Furthermore, when they reach the ocean, all the great rivers—that is, the Ganges, Yamunā, Aciravatī, Sarabhū, and Mahī—lose their names and clans and are simply considered ‘the ocean’.
ai-ud5.5:22.2_0: In the same way, when they go forth from the lay life to homelessness, all four castes—aristocrats, brahmins, merchants, and workers—lose their former names and clans and are simply considered ‘Sakyan ascetics’.
ai-ud5.5:22.3_0: When they go forth from the lay life to homelessness,
ai-ud5.5:22.4_0: This is the fourth thing the mendicants love about this teaching and training.
ai-ud5.5:23.1_0: Just as the ocean does not decrease or fill up because of all the rivers in the world that flow into it or the rain that falls into it,
ai-ud5.5:23.2_0: In the same way, even if many monks are extinguished without remainder, there is no decrease or filling up of the element of extinguishment.
ai-ud5.5:23.3_0: Even if many monks are extinguished without remainder, there is no decrease or filling up of the element of extinguishment.
ai-ud5.5:23.4_0: This is the fifth thing the mendicants love about this teaching and training.
ai-ud5.5:24.1_0: Just as the ocean has only one taste, the taste of salt,
ai-ud5.5:24.2_0: In the same way, this teaching and training has one taste, the taste of freedom.
ai-ud5.5:24.3_0: That, monks, this Dhamma and Discipline has one taste, the taste of freedom,
ai-ud5.5:24.4_0: This is the sixth thing the mendicants love about this teaching and training.
ai-ud5.5:25.1_0: The ocean is full of many kinds of treasures, such as pearls, gems, beryl, conch, quartz, coral, silver, gold, rubies, and emeralds.
ai-ud5.5:25.2_0: so too, this Dhamma and Discipline has many precious things, countless precious things,
ai-ud5.5:25.2_1: These are the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, the four right efforts, the four bases of psychic power, the five faculties, the five powers, the seven awakening factors, and the noble eightfold path.
ai-ud5.5:25.3_0: The four kinds of mindfulness meditation are present.
ai-ud5.5:25.4_0: This is the seventh thing the mendicants love about this teaching and training.
ai-ud5.5:26.1_0: Many great beings live in the ocean, such as leviathans, leviathan-gulpers, leviathan-gulper-gulpers, demons, dragons, and fairies. In the ocean there are life-forms a hundred leagues long, or even two hundred, three hundred, four hundred, or five hundred leagues long.
ai-ud5.5:26.2_0: In the same way, great beings live in this teaching and training, and these are those beings. The stream-enterer and the one practicing to realize the fruit of stream-entry. The once-returner and the one practicing to realize the fruit of once-return. The non-returner and the one practicing to realize the fruit of non-return.
ai-ud5.5:26.3_0: When there are great beings on this spiritual path, these are those beings.”
ai-ud5.5:26.4_0: This is the eighth thing the mendicants love about this teaching and training.
ai-ud5.5:26.5_0: Seeing these eight incredible and amazing things, the mendicants love this teaching and training.”
ai-ud5.5:27.1_0: Then, knowing the significance of this, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
ai-ud5.5:28.1_0: The rain saturates things that are covered up;
ai-ud5.5:28.4_0: And it will not be rained upon.”
